questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency as a case of head injury, following a head on collision road traffic accident. His BP is 90/60 mmHg. Tachycardia is present. Most likely diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In this case scenario try to understand that if a patient has been in a road traffic accident with head injury he never suffers an isolated head injury, there is a high chance that patient has abdominal and extremity injury and they need to be ruled out. In this case patient is hypotensive after a road traffic accident, please note that a patient with isolated head injury will never present with hypotension as skull is a bony cavity and patient never exsanguinates after an isolated head injury. So in this case scenario patient most likely has blunt abdominal trauma as a cause of hypotension due to intra abdominal bleed. Options A,B and C are false as they will never lead to hypotension on their own and they are diagnosed on CT scan and can not be diagnosed clinically.

choices.text: Air embolism through external jugular vein

questions.text: The probable cause of sudden death in a case superficial injury to neck is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) With penetrating injury to neck, air embolism is an important complication which should be considered while treating this condition. Because of penetrating injury to the neck there is a possibility of external jugular vein being communicated with the environment and if this occurs air can be sucked in and if large amount of air gets sucked in it can cause a massive air embolism leading to sudden cardiac arrest. Options A, C and D can also lead to death in patients of penetrating neck injury but they rarely lead to sudden death in patients.

questions.text: In a blast injury, which of the following organ is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Organs which are vulnerable to blast injury are the hollow viscus which have a fluid air interface, solid organs are not affected by blast injury. Among the given options liver is a solid organ with no air fluid interface so it is least affected in blast injury. Tympanic membrane are the most commonly affected structure in a blast injury Lungs are also commonly affected and degree of lung damage is a prognostic indicator of severity of blast injury.

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty with severe hypotension following a road traffic accident. No external injury is evident. The cause of hypotension is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) intra thoracic and abdominal bleed is the major cause of hypotension in a patient of trauma. Option A that is fractured ribs on their own do not lead to hypotension. Option D that is intracranial bleed is never a cause of hypotension on its own.

questions.text: Prognosis in head injury is best given by: (All India 2007, AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glasgow coma scale is the objective scaling system used to quantify the head injury based on motor, verbal and eye response. Glasgow coma scale is the best predictor of prognosis of head injury. Age of the patient can give us a rough idea about the prognosis with better prognosis at the younger age but it is not the best prognostic indicator as it is not reliable and varies from patient to patient. Mode of injury is also suggestive of the prognosis but is not a reliable prognostic indicator. CT head can tell you about the diagnosis and can help you locate the site and type of pathology and can also predict the prognosis of the patient. But CT scan mainly helps in determining the further course of management of the patient rather than predicting the prognosis.

questions.text: A 20-years old male come to causality with head injury. Examination reveals normal consciousness and blood in the tympanic membrane. Most likely cause is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) If there is a base of skull fracture blood can trickle down and get collected in the middle ear and if on clinical examination you see blood behind the tympanic membrane it is suggestive of basilar skull fracture. Extradural haemorrhage, Subdural haemorrhage and intraventricular haemorrhage can not be reliably diagnosed on clinical examination. They can be diagnosed only after we have NCCT Brain Scan report of the patient.

questions.text: After head injury, biconvex, lenticular shape hematoma in CT scan is characteristic of which of the following: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) If NCCT brain of a patient shows a biconvex lentiform opacity it is suggestive of Extra dural hemorrhage. If in NCCT Brain we get a concavoconvex opacity it is suggestive of Sub dural hemorrhage. If in NCCT Brain we get heterogenous opacity in the brain parenchyma it is suggestive of intracebral hematoma Diffuse axonal injury is a condition in which we get small pin point hemorrhage at the junction of grey matter and white matter, NCCT brain is absolutely normal in cases of diffuse axonal injury. Diffuse axonal injury is diagnosed on MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonest source of extradural hemorrhage? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Commonest source of extra dural haemorrhage is rupture of middle meningeal artery. Commonest source of subdural haemorrhage is rupture of the bridging veins.

questions.text: A patient with sudden headache, vomiting and unconsciousness, diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer in this question as this tells about sudden headache, vomiting and unconsciousness and indicates towards sub arachnoid haemorrhage caused because of rupture of berry aneurysm. Option B is intracerebral haemorrhage can occur spontaneously but headache is not a prominent finding in this case. Options C and D occur mostly after trauma and are rare to occur spontaneously.

choices.text: Locate the fracture by shifting the patient side to side
Clear the airway and intubate him

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency with a cervical spine fracture. First thing to do is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) as patient has cervical spine fracture and if you do any other maneuver without fixing the spine then patient can suffer from complete paralysis. So first step in this case is immobilization of spine.

questions.text: Air embolism in neurosurgery maximum in which position?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Venous air embolism is a well known complication of neurosurgical procedures performed in sitting position. Operative site >5 cm above right atrium is a risk factor for VAE More common in posterior fossa surgeries Option B: There is no increased risk of venous air embolism in supine position. Option C and D: Trendelenburg position and left lateral position is used for the treatment of air embolism and does not causes air embolism.

questions.text: A young male with head trauma presented to the casualty with aspiration. Which of the following nerve is affected
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The aspiration indicates gag reflex is not working,hence, glossopharyngeal / vagus nerve is not working. The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is an involuntary reflex involving bilateral pharyngeal muscle contraction and elevation of the soft palate. The afferent limb of the reflex is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which inputs to the nucleus solitarius and the spinal trigeminal nucleus. The efferent limb is supplied by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) from the nucleus ambiguus. All of these are located in the medulla.

questions.text: An old lady fell down and presented after few days with headache and neurological symptoms. What is the source of bleeding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Middle meningeal artery ruptures in EDH. Option B-Lenticular artery ruptures in intracerebral hemorrhage. Option C-Since lady presented after days of trauma,It is likely due to SDH(subdural hemorrhage),which occurs due to rupture of Bridging vessels. Option D-Anterior cerebral artery is less common site for rupture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained a head injury following a motorcycle accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness at the scene. Upon regaining consciousness, he developed severe headache and began to feel drowsy. A CT scan of the head is performed. Which of the following should be the management for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given images shows lenticular shape hyperdense lesion in brain s/o extradural hemorrhage(EDH) causing significant compressive effects on brain. Option A-Anticoagulants are contraindicated. Option B-Immediate surgery is needed to relieve pressure. Option C-Observation in ICU is not done at this stage. Option D-Mannitol to reduce ICP can ge given but surgery is the 1st step.

choices.text: A. Secure Airway, insert ICD, IV fluids.

questions.text: Young male with head trauma comes to casualty. His GCS is 8/15 and SBP 90mmhg. There is absent breath sounds on right side. What is next step in management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absent breath sounds on right side with hypotension is s/o tension pneumothorax. Option A-AIRWAY, ICD, IV FLUIDS should be administered for tension pneumothorax. Option B-IV FLUID alone won't be given. Option C-SHIFT TO OTHER CENTRE can be done only after stabilising the patient. Option D-we can't SEND FOR CT as patient is not stable.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He opens his eyes only in response to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 8 The Glasgow Coma Scale is used to assess the level of consciousness in a patient based on three components: 1. Eye Opening (E): o Spontaneous = 4 o To verbal command = 3 o To pain = 2 o None = 1 (This patient opens eyes to pain = 2). 2. Verbal Response (V): o Oriented = 5 o Confused = 4 o Inappropriate words = 3 o Incomprehensible sounds = 2 o None = 1 (This patient makes incomprehensible sounds = 2). 3. Motor Response (M): o Obeys commands = 6 o Localizes pain = 5 o Withdraws to pain = 4 o Flexion to pain (decorticate) = 3 o Extension to pain (decerebrate) = 2 o None = 1 (This patient withdraws to pain = 4). Total GCS Score: 2 (E) + 2 (V) + 4 (M) = 8.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male recovering from a stroke has the following responses: opens eyes spontaneously, speaks confused sentences, and localizes pain. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 13 1. Eye Opening (E): Spontaneous = 4 2. Verbal Response (V): Confused sentences = 4 3. Motor Response (M): Localizes pain = 5 Total GCS Score: 4 (E) + 4 (V) + 5 (M) = 13.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. He has midface swelling, ecchymosis, and mobility of the upper jaw. On examination, the patient has a fracture involving the maxilla, nasal bridge, and extending through the zygomatic arches. Which type of Le Fort fracture does this most likely represent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Le Fort III Le Fort fractures are classified into three types based on the pattern and extent of fractures in the midface: 1. Le Fort I (Horizontal): o Involves the maxilla at the level of the nasal floor. o Separates the maxillary teeth from the upper face. o Clinical clue: Mobility of the hard palate. 2. Le Fort II (Pyramidal): o Involves the maxilla, nasal bridge, and orbital floor. o Forms a pyramidal shape. o Clinical clue: Mobility of the midface (nasal bridge and maxilla move together). 3. Le Fort III (Craniofacial Disjunction): o Involves the maxilla, nasal bridge, zygomatic arches, and orbits. o Results in complete separation of the facial skeleton from the skull base. o Clinical clue: Entire face moves as a single unit when manipulated. In this case, involvement of the maxilla, nasal bridge, and zygomatic arches indicates Le Fort III fracture.

choices.text: Diplopia due to orbital floor involvement

questions.text: Which of the following signs is most commonly associated with a Le Fort II fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diplopia due to orbital floor involvement A Le Fort II fracture commonly involves the orbital floor, leading to diplopia (double vision) due to injury to the inferior rectus muscle or infraorbital nerve. • Mobility of the hard palate is seen in Le Fort I fractures. • Zygomatic arch involvement is a feature of Le Fort III fractures. • Cranial nerve palsies are rare and usually associated with severe trauma or skull base fractures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a physical altercation. He reports pain and difficulty opening his mouth. On examination, there is malocclusion and tenderness over the left angle of the mandible. Which of the following is the most common site of mandible fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Condylar process The condylar process is the most common site of mandibular fractures, accounting for approximately 30-40% of cases. • Other common sites include the body of the mandible, angle of the mandible, and the symphysis. • Mandibular fractures often occur at multiple sites due to the ring-like structure of the mandible. • Clinical features include pain, malocclusion, trismus (difficulty opening the mouth), and tenderness over the fracture site.

choices.text: Non-contrast CT scan of the face

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to confirm a mandibular fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Plain X-ray (orthopantomogram or OPG) The orthopantomogram (OPG) is the preferred initial imaging modality for mandibular fractures as it provides a panoramic view of the mandible, including the condyles, body, angle, and symphysis. • CT scans are used for complex or multi-site fractures and for pre-surgical planning. • MRI is reserved for soft tissue injuries or temporomandibular joint (TMJ) involvement.
